pullRequest.body:
... and rewrite `Measurable.mul'` and `Measurable.div'` to be in compositional form

From PFR

---

nodes.body:
### PR summary [e3f4a46bd7](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17304/commits/e3f4a46bd71bd25c948d4ae8972238f7297d46c8)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Measurable.smul'`
`+ instance (priority := 100) MeasurableSMulâ‚‚.toMeasurableSMul [MeasurableSMulâ‚‚ M X] :`
`- instance (priority := 100) MeasurableSMulâ‚‚.toMeasurableSMul [MeasurableSMulâ‚‚ M Î²] :`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

tldr; Currently `fun_prop` does not simplify `(f + g) x` to `f x + g x` as a consequence `Measurable.mul` and `Measurable.mul'` are necessary but `Measurable.mul'` should be stated in more general form.

The theorem
```
theorem Measurable.mul [MeasurableMulâ‚‚ M] (hf : Measurable f) (hg : Measurable g) :
    Measurable fun a => f a * g a
```
talks about measurability of `HMul.hMul` in its first and second argument. This theorem is stated in so called *compositional form*. See [doc](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Tactic/FunProp.html) which talks about *compositional* vs *uncurried* form.

The theorem 
```
theorem Measurable.mul' [MeasurableMulâ‚‚ M] (hf : Measurable f) (hg : Measurable g) :
    Measurable (f * g)
```
talks about measurability of  `HMul.hMul` in its third argument. This theorem is stated in so called *uncurried* form.

In `Measurable.mul'`, multiplication is considered as function of three arguments and the theorem talks only about measurability in the third argument. Ideally we would have a theorem talking about measurability in all three arguments. Because multiplication, as a function of three arguments, is high-order function the only way `fun_prop` can properly work with it is if it has the theorem stated in the *compositional form*:
```
@[fun_prop]
theorem Measurable.mul''
    {W M Î± : Type*} [MeasurableSpace W] [MeasurableSpace M] [Mul M] {m : MeasurableSpace Î±} [MeasurableMulâ‚‚ M]
    {f g : W â†’ Î± â†’ M} {h : W â†’ Î±}
    (hf : Measurable (â†¿f)) (hg : Measurable (â†¿g)) (hh : Measurable h):
    Measurable (fun w => ((f w) * (g w)) (h w)) := by simp; fun_prop
```

If you want to consider multiplication as a function of four arguments you should add additional theorem:
```
@[fun_prop]
theorem Measurable.mul'''
    {W M Î± Î² : Type*} [MeasurableSpace W] [MeasurableSpace M] [Mul M] {m : MeasurableSpace Î±} {m' : MeasurableSpace Î²} [MeasurableMulâ‚‚ M]
    {f g : W â†’ Î² â†’ Î± â†’ M} {h : W â†’ Î±} {h' : W â†’ Î²}
    (hf : Measurable (â†¿f)) (hg : Measurable (â†¿g)) (hh : Measurable h) (hh' : Measurable h'):
    Measurable (fun w => ((f w) * (g w)) (h' w) (h w)) := by simp; fun_prop
```
and so on.

Just a reminder, anytime you are unsure if it is a good idea to add theorem or not then turn on `set_option trace.Meta.Tactic.fun_prop.attr true` before declaring `fun_prop` theorem and look at info.

Thanks for the info. I've rewritten `Measurable.mul'` and `Measurable.div'` in compositional form. I have left their `AEMeasurable` version as future work as I then need to start messing around with measures.

Thanks!
maintainer merge
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by grunweg.
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11238835301/job/31244501384)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11238835301/job/31244501848)

Thanks for this PR; tagging more lemmas with fun_prop always seems good.
I wonder about the changes to `Group/Arithmetic.lean`: there's an existing lemma `Measurable.mul` tagged fun_prop; and you're tagging the primed version as well. Both look equivalent, up to a beta reduction.
@lecopivo Is there a pitfall to be aware of, or are these fine to tag?

If that question has a positive answer, feel free to maintainer merge on my behalf.

Thanks for this PR; tagging more lemmas with fun_prop always seems good.
I wonder about the changes to `Group/Arithmetic.lean`: there's an existing lemma `Measurable.mul` tagged fun_prop; and you're tagging the primed version as well. Both look equivalent, up to a beta reduction.
@lecopivo Is there a pitfall to be aware of, or are these fine to tag?

If that question has a positive answer, feel free to maintainer merge on my behalf.
What does this mean? Is there a lemma that should apply but somehow doesn't, or a lemma that's not tagged as fun_prop?
Yes, but actually I think I just forgot that `fun_prop` doesn't discharge with `assumption` by default. I will try again when I'm at a computer
Solved!

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - chore(MeasureTheory/Group/Arithmetic): tag more lemmas with `fun_prop`

### PR summary [e3f4a46bd7](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17304/commits/e3f4a46bd71bd25c948d4ae8972238f7297d46c8)

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Measurable.smul'`
`+ instance (priority := 100) MeasurableSMulâ‚‚.toMeasurableSMul [MeasurableSMulâ‚‚ M X] :`
`- instance (priority := 100) MeasurableSMulâ‚‚.toMeasurableSMul [MeasurableSMulâ‚‚ M Î²] :`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

Thanks for this PR; tagging more lemmas with fun_prop always seems good.
I wonder about the changes to `Group/Arithmetic.lean`: there's an existing lemma `Measurable.mul` tagged fun_prop; and you're tagging the primed version as well. Both look equivalent, up to a beta reduction.
@lecopivo Is there a pitfall to be aware of, or are these fine to tag?

If that question has a positive answer, feel free to maintainer merge on my behalf.

tldr; Currently `fun_prop` does not simplify `(f + g) x` to `f x + g x` as a consequence `Measurable.mul` and `Measurable.mul'` are necessary but `Measurable.mul'` should be stated in more general form.

The theorem
```
theorem Measurable.mul [MeasurableMulâ‚‚ M] (hf : Measurable f) (hg : Measurable g) :
    Measurable fun a => f a * g a
```
talks about measurability of `HMul.hMul` in its first and second argument. This theorem is stated in so called *compositional form*. See [doc](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Tactic/FunProp.html) which talks about *compositional* vs *uncurried* form.

The theorem 
```
theorem Measurable.mul' [MeasurableMulâ‚‚ M] (hf : Measurable f) (hg : Measurable g) :
    Measurable (f * g)
```
talks about measurability of  `HMul.hMul` in its third argument. This theorem is stated in so called *uncurried* form.

In `Measurable.mul'`, multiplication is considered as function of three arguments and the theorem talks only about measurability in the third argument. Ideally we would have a theorem talking about measurability in all three arguments. Because multiplication, as a function of three arguments, is high-order function the only way `fun_prop` can properly work with it is if it has the theorem stated in the *compositional form*:
```
@[fun_prop]
theorem Measurable.mul''
    {W M Î± : Type*} [MeasurableSpace W] [MeasurableSpace M] [Mul M] {m : MeasurableSpace Î±} [MeasurableMulâ‚‚ M]
    {f g : W â†’ Î± â†’ M} {h : W â†’ Î±}
    (hf : Measurable (â†¿f)) (hg : Measurable (â†¿g)) (hh : Measurable h):
    Measurable (fun w => ((f w) * (g w)) (h w)) := by simp; fun_prop
```

If you want to consider multiplication as a function of four arguments you should add additional theorem:
```
@[fun_prop]
theorem Measurable.mul'''
    {W M Î± Î² : Type*} [MeasurableSpace W] [MeasurableSpace M] [Mul M] {m : MeasurableSpace Î±} {m' : MeasurableSpace Î²} [MeasurableMulâ‚‚ M]
    {f g : W â†’ Î² â†’ Î± â†’ M} {h : W â†’ Î±} {h' : W â†’ Î²}
    (hf : Measurable (â†¿f)) (hg : Measurable (â†¿g)) (hh : Measurable h) (hh' : Measurable h'):
    Measurable (fun w => ((f w) * (g w)) (h' w) (h w)) := by simp; fun_prop
```
and so on.

Just a reminder, anytime you are unsure if it is a good idea to add theorem or not then turn on `set_option trace.Meta.Tactic.fun_prop.attr true` before declaring `fun_prop` theorem and look at info.

Thanks for the info. I've rewritten `Measurable.mul'` and `Measurable.div'` in compositional form. I have left their `AEMeasurable` version as future work as I then need to start messing around with measures.
